context: the patient is a 5-year-old male, who was last evaluated by dr. f approximately one year ago for suspected nasal obstruction, possible sleep apnea.
patient with suspected nasal obstruction, possible sleep apnea.
dr. f's assessment at that time was the patient not had sleep apnea and did not truly even seem to have allergic rhinitis.
he has been tried on some nasal steroids but they only use this on a p.r.n. basis about one or two days every month and we are unsure if that has even helped at all, probably not.
it sounds like he is snoring loudly and does have some nasal obstruction at nighttime.
he also is sniffing a lot through his nose.
anterior rhinoscopy does demonstrate boggy turbinates bilaterally with minimal amount of watery rhinorrhea.
anterior rhinoscopy does demonstrate boggy turbinates bilaterally with minimal amount of watery rhinorrhea.
the patient tympanic membranes are clear and intact bilaterally.
there is no middle ear effusion.
i have given them prescription for nasacort aqua one spray to each nostril twice a day.
if he continues to have problems, i think at that point we may consider performing a transnasal exam in the office to examine his adenoid bed.
he may also need an allergy evaluation at that point if he continues to have problems.

should the mother still have concerns regarding his sleeping at our next visit or should his symptoms worsen (i did instruct her call us if it worsens), we may even need to pursue a sleep study just to settle that issue once and for all.
